codefordc.description:
Join us at iStrategyLabs for more of that great civic hacking that you know and love.

6:30 - 7:00 Participants arrive and socialize. 


7:00 - 7:15 Group introductions and announcements from participants and organizers.

7:15 - 9:00 Hacking! Project teams break out to work.  If you are new, join the new member orientation.

~7:30 Food delivered. 

9:00 - 9:15 Everyone reconvenes and shares reactions to and progress made over the last two hours. Show and tell if time/resources allow it. Thank you and goodnight.

9:15 We head out to happy hour.

Notes: 

• Bring cash for food and drink! Pay what you can.

If you are new to Code for DC: 

• Bring a laptop if you can (it’s ok if you can’t).

• Take a look at our projects.

• Review the Code for DC Code of Conduct.

• Feel free to contact us with any questions, concerns, etc.

• If you had a good time, join Google Group, Slack, and this Meetup group to stay in the loop.
codefordc.name: Civic Hacknight

other.description:
Front End Hack Night (FEHN) is a study group where women can come together and help each other learn and understand web development. We welcome devs of all levels and encourage those with more experience to help out those that are just starting. There's always at least one mentor or leader present to help you with best practices or to guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem! Laptops

In order to maximize your benefits from FEHN, please bring your laptop. Extra computers will not be available at the event. Even if you have never coded before, you will be coding at FEHN!

Meetup Agenda Every study group will have the following format:
• 6:30pm - Setup

• 6:40 - 6:50pm - Quick introductions

• 6:50 - 8:15pm - Code!

• 8:15 - 8:30pm - Wrap Up

Resources

To learn more about us please visit our Github page - http://bit.ly/frontendhacknight

• First Timer's Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-first-timers • HTML Study Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-html-guide • JavaScript Study Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-js-guide Building Access

Certain building management companies require Meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy. In case the location requires access to the building, contact the group lead if information is provided or drop a comment on the Meetup page. We'll come and get you.

Welcome This event is intended to be exclusively open for women; we are trans* friendly.
other.name: Front End Lab

other.description:
Women Who Code is partnering with Technical.ly this August for Super Meetup. Join us at WeWork's Manhattan Laundry location (opening soon!) for free drinks and snacks to celebrate the meetup community in DC (and recruit new members!) Please RSVP here >> Super Meetup 2016


  ------

Details on Super Meetup:


Come have a free beer, grab a snack and get to know one another at Super Meetup! 

Super Meetup is a gathering of the most-connected members of the local tech, startup, and entrepreneurial scene. It’s a chance to make new friends and learn more about local tech and entrepreneurial resources and tech-focused meetup groups.

The idea of the Super Meetup is simple: meetups are integral to any tech scene. Every now and then, it makes sense to rally the leaders of tech-related meetups in town and gather for one big mixer. The idea is to connect people with groups they may not have otherwise known about.

There are dozens of active user groups in DC, but we don't often enough come together to make sure we know each other, know which groups are still active, what groups are doing, and where there is room for collaboration.

#SuperMeetup16
other.name: Super Meetup with Technical.ly DC

other.description:
We're a group of women who want to learn and develop our Python scripting skills. Some of us are professional developers and data scientists, others are hobbyists, and some are just beginning. The study group is intended for everyone who wishes to learn more about the Python programming language. Folks of all skill levels are welcome!


We host beginners night on the first Wednesday of every month, which caters especially for absolute beginners and people with basic familiarity.

All other study group nights will generally cover more advanced topics and work on projects more in depth, according to everyone's interests.

(Please bring a laptop!) 

Note: This Women Who Code DC event is intended to be exclusively open for women; we are trans* friendly.
other.name: Python Lab

other.description:
Tonight we're going to do another instance of one of our most popular recent events: building a surrealist Rails app.

Inspired by a workshop by Terian Koscik at RailsConf 2016, we’ll be building Rails apps in the exquisite corpse style. We’ll be working in groups and basic knowledge of Rails and databases will be very helpful. To find out more information checkout these links! 

Terian’s page on this workshop:

http://pineconedoesthings.com/surreal.html 

Exquisite corpse wikipedia page:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exquisite_corpse

Meetup Agenda 

• 6:30pm - Setup

• 7pm - Break for quick introductions

• 7:15pm - 8:30 pm - Build surrealist Rails apps!

Contact policy at buildings that need access

Certain building managements requires meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you. Want to be a Ruby on Rails Lead? If you are passionate about learning ROR with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out! Drop us a message or email us and let us know that you are interested in helping us with the Rails study group!

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

https://github.com/womenwhocodedc/organization/blob/master/learning-resources/ruby-on-rails/rails_guide.md

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.

Request to join our Slack channel for communication:

http://bit.ly/wwcdcslack
other.name: Ruby on Rails: Collaborate on a Surrealist Rails App

other.description:
You must register on Eventbrite. Use the code WCM for $5 off.

Networking isn't just for jobs. It's for helping you with sales, funding, ideas and support. It's for the long-term relationships that remind someone of you when they have a position or allow you to reach out when you need an introduction. It's about building professional connections that create value for you and for them. And sometimes it's about building friendships.

And if you aren't networking or aren't doing it effectively...this class is for you.

You should join us...


- If you've ever felt awkward at a conference or a party, wondered how to break into a conversation pod, pretended to be busy on your phone to hide your shyness or otherwise wondered how to network in person

- If you're comfortable with people but never seem to close any deals or develop relationships out of events

- If you are considering a career change and need a refresher

**PLUS: we have a practice session over food & drinks! **

How it works

We start with class, have a practice break with drinks & food, unpack the experience in the 2nd session and then hang out after to further sharpen skills.

What we'll cover

Gearing up: finding good networking opportunities, creating an introduction and networking pitch, pre-event planning.

Mechanics: how to enter & exit conversations, where to stand for maximum value, 

Handling Challenges: how to deal with challenging people, dealing with shyness and other quirks

Effective follow up and how to maximize your networking reach: email followup, twitter and other social media rules, ideas for staying visible without being annoying

After the workshop there will be optional practice networking so you can put what you've learned to the test!

Instructor

Jasmine Sante, Founder, Sante Strategies & Web Content Mavens
www.santestrategies.com
www.webmavensdc.com
other.name: Work The Room: Networking in the Wild

other.description:
Come join PyLadies for Happy Hour! It doesn't matter if you're a newbie or an expert - stop by for a drink and to meet other PyLadies and talk Python.


Be sure to bring any ideas or requests for what you'd like from PyLadies DC, too. We'd love to hear from you while you're there!

Hope to see you soon!
other.name: PyLadies Happy Hour

other.description:
Coders and commuting: how do apps change the way we drive? This month we'll hear from tech companies with apps that help people share the road. We'll meet on the 12th floor of WeWork's new Crystal City location. Doors open at 6:00 with pizza courtesy of our sponsors Mobility Lab and RideAmigos. Presentations start at 6:30. 

• Anna Petrone will present how Split is building a scalable and efficient shared ride system. 

• Andriy Klymchuk will show how Sameride was created, a mobile app for communities of commuters.


• Numaan Akram from Rally will show how their technology connects riders to vans & buses for trips that vary as widely as your daily commute to the Super Bowl.


• Prachi Vakharia will show how RideAmigos integrates transportation network companies into city planning.

• Jay Subramaniam will talk about Getaround's software and hardware technologies.

• David Miller will share what he learned after launching Ride Leads, the nation’s first connected-traveller and packaged mobility platform.


• Antonio Zugaldia will present Mapbox Drive and show how to use it to build your own ridesharing app.

Read about our previous Playing with Traffic event: "Safer streets with better data."


     🚗 💨             🚚 💨             🚙 💨             🚛 💨             🚕 💨 


Coming up in September, we'll be back in DC with Bike Hack Night VI.


As always, stay tuned to @techiesdc for updates.
other.name: Playing with Traffic ][

other.description:
Join your fellow data visualizers for David Aja’s presentation of the EFS Dashboard – a dash boarding and analytics tool he coded and designed himself in Shiny. David designed EFS to help simplify the process of analyzing the results of GAO’s annual employee feedback survey. David says that goal of EFS is t to reduce the amount of labor required to get to survey graphs- through building a cloud cloud-based way to collect and analyze survey results.

RStudio developed Shiny as a web application framework for R, designed to turn your analyses into interactive web applications. No HTML, CSS, or JavaScript knowledge required.

Hiring? Job Seeking? Explore our Candidate Network. Datable.org

Building your brand in tech? Sponsor DC2


Agenda:

• 6:30 -7:00 Doors Open and Networking

• 7ish - Announcements

• 7:15 - 8 - David Presents EFS Dashboard

• 8 – 8:20 – Questions and Answers

• Wrap Up and Data Drinks (Big Hunt)

E. David Aja is a Data Analyst at the U.S. Government Accountability Office, an organization that conducts oversight of federal agencies for Congress. He has worked on a wide assortment of projects there, such as analyses of federal contracting data and assessments of weapons system acquisition at DoD.  He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Philosophy from Cornell University, and Master’s degrees in Public Administration and Public Policy from Syracuse University and the Hertie School of Governance in Berlin.

David says he got into data visualization with R and Shiny because “I was tired of fighting with Stata and losing.” His favorite beer is Coney Island Mermaid Pilsner.


Hiring? Job Seeking? Explore our Candidate Network. Datable.org

Building your brand in tech? Sponsor DC2
other.how_to_find_us: Sign in with the guard and come to the 2nd floor
other.name: Happy Shiny Web Apps Everywhere

other.description:
Say you're building a simple website with five pages linked together, and a simple navigation bar at the top. You make some changes to the code and want to know if everything still works. So you open your local version of the webpage and click through each button on the navigation bar to make sure they each still lead to the right destination. Not hard, and it doesn't take long.

But now imagine you make some changes to a more complex app--one with 20 pages, a login system, various forms, and content that should look different depending on which type of user you're logged in as. You could come up with a checklist of all the buttons you'd have to manually click on—and forms you’d have to test-submit in various ways—while logged in as various different users, checking to make sure your changes didn’t accidentally blow up an obscure but necessary function of your website. Repeating a long list of tests every time you make a small update to your app would get repetitive and tedious. 

Thankfully, computers love doing repetitive and tedious tasks for us! Automated testing—when we write code to perform tests on other code—helps us as developers to save time, expose poorly written code, confidently expand or update our apps, sleep better at night knowing that bugs are permanently addressed, and even think more critically when we sit down to write an app from scratch. 

In this meetup we'll examine one of the most popular testing frameworks for Rails applications, called RSpec. 

***


Meetup Agenda
• 6:30pm - Setup and start working

• 7pm - Break for quick introductions

• 7:15pm - 8:30 pm - RSpec presentation

Contact policy at buildings that need access

Certain building managements requires meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you. Want to be a Ruby on Rails Lead? If you are passionate about learning ROR with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out! Drop us a message or email us and let us know that you are interested in helping us with the Rails study group!

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

https://github.com/womenwhocodedc/organization/blob/master/learning-resources/ruby-on-rails/rails_guide.md

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.

Request to join our Slack channel for communication:

http://bit.ly/wwcdcslack
other.name: Ruby on Rails: Intro to Testing with RSpec

other.description:
Please note the date change.

Reminder: You MUST register on Eventbrite to attend.

Content marketing is a method of creating and sharing relevant and compelling content that engages your existing audience and attracts a new one.

Join us as we discuss content marketing with an emphasis on engagement:
* reaching and attracting new audiences
* building stronger levels of brand engagement
* encouraging participation
* completing calls-to-action such as purchasing, joining, advocating and sharing

Discussion points:

- The essentials of content marketing 
- Content marketing as an engagement tool
- Using content marketing to attract new audiences  
- Writing effective calls-to-action 
- Content marketing techniques for locating and involving brand advocates  
- Ideas for engaging new and existing audiences in your brand and mission

SPEAKERS

Tina Johnson-Marcel, Director of Flagship Content, Capital One

Additional speaker information pending confirmation


AGENDA

6:30 - Check-in, drinks & light appetizers
7:00 - Presentations
8:15 - Q & A
8:30 - More networking
9:00 - Adjourn
other.name: Content Marketing: Tools for Engagement

other.description:
This meetup is going to be a split level git and GitHub night: one group will focus on intro to git and GitHub, and one group will focus on leveling up your git.

You might be a good fit for the intro group if: 

• you've never heard of git or GitHub

• you've heard of git and/or GitHub but you've never used it before

• you've tried to use it on personal projects but have had trouble or just want a refresher course

You might be a good fit for the leveling up group if:


• you're comfortable using git personally but want to learn how to use it in teams/for collaboration

• you want to lean more about best practices like keeping sensitive information out of version control

• you want to learn more about commands like "git rebase" and "git squash"

More event details to be added soon!

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.

Request to join our Slack group for communication:
http://bit.ly/wwcdcslack
other.name: Git and GitHub Night: Split Level

other.description:
Interested in building big data solutions? If so, please join us this August to learn about the cloud services provided by Microsoft's Azure Platform.

Agenda

6:30 PM -- Networking & Food 

6:55 PM -- Greetings & Prizes

7:00 PM -- Building Big Data Solutions in Azure Data Platform - Mostafa Elzoghbi

9:00 PM -- Post event drinks

Directions

There is ample parking surrounding the JHU APL building. Make sure you go to the south campus and not the main area in the north.

Talks

Building Big Data Solutions in Azure Data Platform

The session covers how to get started to build big data solutions in Azure. Azure provides various Hadoop cluster types for Hadoop ecosystem. The session covers the basic understanding of HDInsight clusters including: Apache Hadoop, HBase, Storm and Spark. The session covers how to integrate with HDInsight in .NET using different Hadoop integration frameworks and libraries. The session convers Data platform services in Azure to build end-to-end big data solutions including IoT, batch, streaming and analytics products in cloud based data solutions. The session is a demo driven and covers how to work with HDInsight clusters to build efficient and scalable solutions.


Speakers

Mostafa Elzoghbi is a Microsoft Sr. Technical Evangelist based in DC. Mostafa is specialized in Azure architecture and development, Office 365 development and administration, .NET development, and enterprise product development. I am an experienced architect in building cloud based solutions and a data nerd. Prior to joining Microsoft, Mostafa was awarded a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional (MVP) award for five consecutive years. Mostafa holds a M.Sc. of Computer Science and holds several Microsoft certifications. Mostafa can be reached on Twitter @MostafaElzoghbi and at http://www.mostafaelzoghbi.com/
other.name: Building Big Data Solutions in Azure Data Platform

other.description:
Bike Hack Night is a show & tell of bicycle-related apps, data visualizations, and gadgets. We are thrilled to be co-sponsored by REI, which has invited us to the REI Community Space at Wunder Garten as part of the #unitedoutside celebration. And thanks to co-sponsor Mobility Lab for making this event possible. Doors open at 6:00; REI will be providing s'mores, and beer will be available for purchase. Speakers will begin at 6:30.

Our speakers are:

• Ryan Abrahamsen will show how Terrain360 maps bike trails to panoramic images.


• Justin Molineaux of Baas Bikes will show how smartphones can create low-cost, data-rich bikeshare systems.


• Tom Lee will show how he collected bike safety data using ultrasonic sensors, ESP8266 wifi microcontrollers and smartphones.


• Eric Brelsford will show you how to get your city's bike lanes into OpenStreetMap and talk about why you would want to.


• Darren Buck and James Graham will present DDOT's new GIS street data, and bicycling Level of Traffic Stress analysis.


• Kate Rabinowitz will dig into Bike to Work Day 2016, By the Numbers.


• Alexandra Ulsh will show how DCFemTech built a map for WABA showing proximity to bike infrastructure.


See what happened at Bike Hack Night V:  Piecing together data to improve biking in DC.

Our hashtag is #bikehacknight. Follow @techiesdc for "Transportation Techies" updates.

(And don't forget Playing with Traffic II is Thursday, August 18.)
other.name: Bike Hack Night VI

venue.name: REI Community Space at Wunder Garten

The agenda will include a lecture that covers Ruby and Rails and an installfest to help you set up Rails on your own computer.

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.

Please bring a laptop to the event so you can participate in the installfest!

Check out our ROR guide for more info about what we will be covering on Wednesday: http://bit.ly/wwcrailsguide

Front End Hack Night (FEHN) is a study group where women can come together and help each other learn and understand web development. We welcome devs of all levels and encourage those with more experience to help out those that are just starting. There's always at least one mentor or leader present to help you with best practices or to guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem! Laptops

In order to maximize your benefits from FEHN, please bring your laptop. Extra computers will not be available at the event. Even if you have never coded before, you will be coding at FEHN!

Meetup Agenda Every study group will have the following format:
• 6:30pm - Setup

• 6:40 - 6:50pm - Quick introductions

• 6:50 - 8:15pm - Code!

• 8:15 - 8:30pm - Wrap Up

Resources

To learn more about us please visit our Github page - http://bit.ly/frontendhacknight

• First Timer's Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-first-timers • HTML Study Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-html-guide • JavaScript Study Guide: http://bit.ly/fehn-js-guide Building Access

Certain building management companies require Meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy. In case the location requires access to the building, contact the group lead if information is provided or drop a comment on the Meetup page. We'll come and get you.

Welcome This event is intended to be exclusively open for women; we are trans* friendly.
other.name: Front End Lab

other.description:
Everyone is looking forward to hearing about *your* cool hack. The format is informal, engaging, and friendly: presenters have *5* minutes to show off their hack (it goes faster than you’d expect) and then the audience has 5 minutes to ask questions, make jokes, and suggest ideas and feedback. The hacks that people present are anything from how to train your dog to text you when it needs a walk to [something more serious... like blenders made out of artichokes]. Show us what you’ve got! But remember: no startup pitches, no dull work projects, no deckware!

Presentation signups are here:


http://bit.ly/presentatdc


See you at the meetup, at WeWork Chinatown. We try to start on-time at 6:30. Sometimes we have free food (bonus!). Big thanks to WeWork for hosting us! We love WeWork! We love you! We love hacks! <3
other.name: Round 36: Unfair Witty Outburst

other.description:
Interested in learning how to build Android apps with an awesome group of women? Looking to build your first app or build on existing skills? Come to our weekly Android Lab! We welcome women with all levels of Android experience (including none). ***Please bring your laptop to this event as computers will not be provided.***


Resources

Beginners should check out our Android Getting Started Guide. It's chock full of information to get you up and running. It is a work in progress and we'll be adding as we go. Suggestions welcomed!

All Women Welcome

This event is intended to be exclusively open for women; we are trans* friendly.

Can't Come This Week, but Want to Stay in Touch?

Please join our Slack group to talk about all things Android.
other.name: Android Lab

other.description:
We're a group of women who want to learn and develop our Python scripting skills.  Most of us are beginners and each meet up is geared for this level. We also have some professional developers and data scientists who attend. The study group is intended for everyone who wishes to learn more Python programming language. Folks of all skill levels are welcome!


We host beginners night on the first Wednesday of every month, which caters especially for absolute beginners and people with basic familiarity.  We help load Python and then complete a mini-program.

Other study group nights will cover basic intro into one of Python's topics and we'll then work on a mini-program line-by line.  Targeted to the beginner group.  The goal here is for you to understand the Python lesson, practice hands-on coding applying this knowledge and complete a mini-program each night. 


Please bring a laptop!

Note: 

This Women Who Code DC event is intended to be exclusively open for women; we are trans* friendly.
other.name: Python Lab

other.description:
Meetup Agenda


• 6:30pm - Setup and start working

• 7pm - Break for quick introductions

• 7:15pm - 8:30 pm - Open Lab, tech talk, or project

Contact policy at buildings that need access

Certain building managements requires meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you. Want to be a Ruby on Rails Lead? If you are passionate about learning ROR with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out! Drop us a message or email us and let us know that you are interested in helping us with the Rails study group!

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

https://github.com/womenwhocodedc/organization/blob/master/learning-resources/ruby-on-rails/rails_guide.md

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.

Request to join our Slack channel for communication:

http://bit.ly/wwcdcslack
other.name: Ruby on Rails

other.description:
Friends,


This Year DevFestDC is scheduled as a two day event. 

Register in the Eventbrite Link.

This location conveniently located near McLean Metro Station in Silver Line.

DevFestDC is around the corner (Sep 23 & 24) and we have great line of speakers, code labs, sessions in store for all. The entry fee for this 2 day event including breakfast, lunch on both days and happy hours on Friday at CapitalOne is only $19.99 if you sign up before Sep 1. We will update the sessions and speakers at sessions and Speakers 

Plan to attend both days or either one of the days depending on your schedule!

More Updates on Sessions/Speakers coming at www.devfestdc.org 

Following is a sampling of speakers:

• Katy Kasmai (Google) - Moonshot

• Ray Tsang (Google) - Kubernetes

• Bret McGowen (Google) - Tensor Flow / Machine Learning Workshop 

• Jared Sheehan (Capital One) - Making Sense - Unleash the Power of Sensory Data to Understand User Context

• Sam Edwards (Capital One) - Espresso: A Screenshot is Worth 1,000 Words

• Noble Ackerson (Byte an Atom Research) - User-centered Product Validation

• Marc Boorshtein (Tremolo Security, Inc.) - Open Source Identity Management with Kubernetes RBAC

• Eric Fung (Shopify) - Set Course for Notifications… Engage!

• Mark Murphy (CommonsWare) - Doing Periodic Work: Another Android Headache


This event is only possible with the generous sponsorship from the sponsors and community

Please don't RSVP here. RSVP at Eventbrite

Great speakers, code labs (Machine Learning), workshops and panels planned.
other.how_to_find_us: DevFestDC, Google, Cloud, Containers, Cloud Platform, App Engine, Compute Engine, Containers, Developers, Polymer, Meteor, AngularJS, Java, Python, Capital One, AWS, Azure, BigData, Hadoop, Machine Learning, Tensorflow
other.name: DevFestDC - 2016 - Sep 23/24 @ CapitalOne

other.description:
(We are in the planning stages so information is preliminary)

Registration is through Eventbrite


Note: This event is limited to 45 attendees. 

== MavenMini: Association Web Mini-Conference ==

Five hours of presentations, discussions and networking focused on association websites and digital properties.

Our first MavenMini is August 11th on Web User Experience.

Agenda

4:00 - Registration and Networking 
4:30 - Session 1: Websites
5:30 - Networking and Light Dinner 
6:00 - Session 2: Digital Marketing
7:00 - Networking Over Cocktails 
7:30 - Session 3: Tools & Management
8:30 - Networking Over Coffee & Dessert
9:00 - Adjourn

Topics

Call for Speakers: We are looking for presentations that present new information, a unique approach, a detailed overview of a complex element, etc. See below for more information.

These are guiding topic descriptions - in draft form - and are not complete lists.

Session 1: Websites
Redesigns, website tuning, responsive design

Session 2: Digital Marketing
Newsletters, email marketing, integrated communications, advocacy, calls-to-action.

Session 3: Tools & Site Management
Integrating external tools with web properties (AMS, eLearning, etc), website management and governance

Call for Speakers

Note: We are particularly interested in association staff presenters. 

Talks should meet one of these criteria: 


  - Gives new information or shows an innovative approach to established techniques
  - Presents a thought provoking or intriguing idea in an actionable context (i.e. inclusive design as a theory and how to put it in practice)
  - Applies complex technique to a range applications

Talks should also speak to our core audiences: web managers, front-end devs, designers, usability & content strategists, etc.

Topic Areas

Coming soon. Feel free to suggest something.

For more information, email [masked]. Please include your topic idea/ideas and background.
other.name: MavenMini: Association Web

other.name: Round 37: Cell Out

other.description:
Topic Overview: The Business Value of Data Wrangling

Data Wrangling and Data Preparation have emerged as key topics in the world of Information Management and Business Analytics.  However, many people are not familiar with these terms, let alone the details these topics.  Data volumes are growing exponentially, the speed at which data crosses people's desks increases almost daily, and the various types of data to be analyzed can be overwhelming.  The industry has developed a powerful range of tools to store data and an equally powerful range of tools to analyze data.  However, to date, there has not a been significant amount of focus on careful preparation and active manipulation of this data to allow for more thorough approaches to data and business analytics.  This presentation will cover relevant background and provide a foundation for understanding the business value of Data Wrangling.  Topics include:


What is Data Wrangling?

• Data Wrangling vs. Data Preparation

• Market and Analyst Overview

• Common Data Wrangling Tasks

• The Best Time and Place

• Connecting Data Wrangling and Business Value 

Speaker Bio:

Bob Moore is a Vice President of Solutions Consulting at TIBCO.  He has over 15 years of Business Intelligence and Data Visualization experience.  Data Wrangling and Data Preparation, in conjunction with visual analytics tools, has been an  area of focus for the last decade.  He has experience with data from numerous industries and varied use cases.
other.name: October Meetup - The Business Value of Data Wrangling

other.description:
(We are in the planning stages so information is preliminary)

Registration is through Eventbrite

Note: Limited to 40 attendees. Tickets are released in tiers. Save $10-35 by registering early, which also helps with planning the speaker list. 

== MavenMini: Content Strategy & Content Management Mini-Conference ==

Five hours of content strategy, content management and CMS presentations, discussions and networking!

Our first MavenMini is August 11th on Web User Experience.

Agenda

4:00 - Registration and Networking 
4:30 - Session 1: Content Organization
5:30 - Networking and Light Dinner 
6:00 - Session 2: Content Display 
7:00 - Networking Over Cocktails 
7:30 - Session 3: Content Management
8:30 - Networking Over Coffee & Dessert
9:00 - Adjourn

Topics

We are looking for presentations on these topics that present new information, a unique approach, a detailed overview of a complex element, etc. See below for more information.

These are guiding topic descriptions - in draft form.

Session 1: Content Organization
Taxonomy, Information Architecture, Navigation

Session 2: Content Display
Responsive content. Mobile content. Integrated content. Channels.

Session 3: Planning & Tuning
Content Management and Content Management Systems. Governance.

Note: If possible, we'll add a section on content creation, including voice & style.

Speakers

The speaker list will be posted in late August.

Call for Speakers: Criteria

Talks should meet one of these criteria: 
  - Gives new information or shows an innovative approach to established techniques 
  - Presents a thought provoking or intriguing idea in an actionable context (i.e. inclusive design as a theory and how to put it in practice) 
  - Applies complex technique to a range applications

Talks should also speak to our core audiences: web managers, front-end devs, designers, usability & content strategists, etc.

Call for Speakers: Topic Areas

You are welcome to suggest alternate topics. 

- Taxonomy, tagging
- Navigation & IA
- Responsive content
- Mobile content
- Integrated & multi-channel content approaches
- Web CMS - selecting, working with, integrating
- Content management, content governance - techniques

For more information, email [masked]. Please include your topic idea/ideas and background.
other.name: MavenMini: Content Strategy & Content Management

other.description:
(We haven't finalized a date. You are welcome to register but be aware that are in the planning stages and information is preliminary)

Registration is through Eventbrite


Looking for the Association Web mini-conference? Here

== MavenMini: Nonprofit Web Mini-Conference ==

Five hours of presentations, discussions and networking focused on both nonprofit websites and digital marketing, advocacy & engagement tools

> Meet your nonprofit peers and share stories over dinner, drinks and dessert.
> Listen to sessions focused on the specific needs and interests of nonprofits.
> Hear talks from other nonprofit leaders, from experts in nonprofits websites and from thought leaders.
> Follow-up with fellow attendees after the event.

Agenda

4:00 - Registration and Networking 
4:30 - Session 1: Websites
5:30 - Networking and Light Dinner 
6:00 - Session 2: Digital Marketing, Advocacy and Engagement
7:00 - Networking Over Cocktails 
7:30 - Session 3: Tools and Integrated Marketing
8:30 - Networking Over Coffee & Dessert
9:00 - Adjourn

Call for Speakers & Topics

We are looking for speakers on the topics below.

We are interested in hearing from nonprofit staff. You do not need to be an experienced speaker!! This is a small conference and a great opportunity for you to get your feet wet with speaking to a group.

Generally, talks range from 15-25 minutes and should include a slideshow or other visual presentation.

 Criteria

 Talks should meet one of these criteria:

- Gives new information or shows an innovative approach to established techniques
- Presents a thought provoking or intriguing idea in an actionable context (i.e. inclusive design as a theory and how to put it in practice)
- Applies complex technique to a range applications

Talks should also speak to our core audiences: web managers, front-end devs, designers, usability & content strategists, etc. We are specifically looking for nonprofit staff to participate. You do not need to be an experienced speaker.

Topics

These are just guiding topic descriptions - not intended to be exhaustive or literal.

Session 1: Websites
Topics such as: redesigns, building community, conference sites, etc

Session 2: Digital Marketing
Topics such as newsletters, email marketing, integrated communications, advocacy, converting prospects, etc.

Session 3: Tools & CRM
Topics such as integrating external tools with web properties (CRMs, etc), website management and governance, persuading leadership, etc.

For more information on speaking, email [masked]. Please include a topic sentence (or topic idea/ideas) and a brief background. If you have several ideas/topics, share them all!
other.name: MavenMini: Nonprofit Web [date TBD]
